channel.title: Portfolios on Clare's GIS Portfolio
channel.description: Recent content in Portfolios on Clare's GIS Portfolio

item.title: Blue
item.description: Once I’d discovered the UKHO site with lots of detailed bathymetry for the UK, it seemed obvious to produce a map of Loch Torridon. In the end, it worked best to concentrate on one part of the Loch. Bathymetry of the Loch Torridon Narrows Data I used 2m, 4m and 8m resolution bathymetry of Loch Torridon from UKHO Seabed Mapping Service Ordnance Survey OpenZoomstack data with OS stylesheets. Tools I used GDAL to convert .

item.title: Elevation
item.description: RGB hillshade with Relief Visualisation Toolbox The idea for this map came from a blog about long barrows by the Avon Valley Archaeological Society. Bury Ditches Hillfort, South Shropshire. Data Data is 1m Lidar DTM from Defra download page. Data acknowledgement for Lidar data - Contains public sector information licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0. Tools I used QGIS to merge lidar data then clip to required area. Relief Visualisation Toolbox which I’d not used before.

item.title: Raster
item.description: These maps are based on a tutorial on terraforming Mars with python. Terraforming Mars Tools I used Python What did I learn? I tried using Venus instead, but areas with no data made it look ugly. Learnt about custom colour ramps in python and using two colour ramps on the same map. Fun to look at the surface of Mars as well.

item.title: Metamapping
Mapping 3D
item.description: Intervisibility between hillforts in South-west Shropshire Tools I used Made in QGIS DTM data preparation done with GDAL at command line. Data Original hillfort kml download from Megalithic Portal search. Had to inspect data and move some hillfort points to highest point of hillfort according to the Lidar data. Is there a way of doing this automatically? Height data is merged from 2 m lidar with OS Open data Terrain 50 to fill the gaps.

item.title: Data challenge: Natural Earth data
item.description: Marine Protection Areas of the North Atlantic Data Natural Earth Data used via Cartopy. Marine Protected Areas data from Protected Planet. Tools I used QGIS to merge shapefiles Python with cartopy package for main processing Inkscape for layout What did I learn? Using cartopy package in python to provide a Natural Earth background for data in a GeoPandas geodataframe. Tried out both raster and vector backgrounds. Useful to discover data available at Protected Planet.

item.title: Movement
item.description: Animation of our walk from Torridon House to Strathcarron Background map © OpenStreetMap Contributors 2022. Used converted gpx track of a walk we did from Torridon House to Strathcarron Hotel via An Ruadh-stac in 2017. Tools I used Generated maps of route with MMQGIS plugin in QGIS Used GIMP to create an animated GIF. What did I learn? Exporting frames with MMQGIS. How to create an animated gif in GIMP! How to keep file sizes right down with page size and resolution.

item.title: Data challenge 3: GHSL
item.description: GHSL = Global Human Settlement Layer The page also provides information about the tools provided, including a tool for coordinate conversion of population grids. Inspiration from: 3D spikes for population data - tutorial from Alastair Rae. Population density of Britain and Ireland Data Global Human Settlement Layer Tools I used QGIS AerialOD Inkscape for final layout (adding text) What did I learn? Useful gridded population data for recommendation to students in future.

item.title: Interactive map
item.description: Torridonian Reflections web map The photographs that pop up on this web map are taken from the exhibition we put on at University of Leeds in 2014. Interactive Torridonian Reflections map. Tools I used Made with qgis2web plugin in QGIS. What did I learn? Hiding fields in layer properties. Changing contents of fields to html with field calculator. The developer of Leaflet js is Ukrainian What do I want to change?

item.title: Elevation
item.description: Heights of British and Irish Hills Data Database of British and Irish Hills. Tools I used Python QGIS Inkscape What did I learn? Plotly in both QGIS and python! Used the python version to export to svg in the end. Symbol levels in QGIS. Sometimes it’s easier or better to finish off a layout in Inkscape. What do I want to change? I’m not happy with the size of the points on the map or the key.

item.title: Lines
item.description: My thoughts for the theme of lines turned towards routes, e.g. railways. In the end I went for a route from one of our extremely enjoyable walks in the Highlands around Torridon. 3D line with labels Inspiration taken from 3D line for a route. Tools I used QGIS with QGIS2threejs extension What did I learn? How to add z values to lines and points Setting up labels in a 3D view in QGIS2threejs and add connectors to points.

item.title: Island(s)
item.description: Flat Holm and Steep Holm Flat Holm and Steep Holm are islands in the Bristol Channel visible from Weston-Super-Mare. I spent many happy holidays in Weston-Super-Mare staying with my grandparents. The maps are inspired by the style of Hamish Haswell-Smith in his Scottish Islands book. Contains OS data © Crown Copyright and database right 2022. Also contains OpenStreetMap data © OpenStreetMap Contributors, 2022. Data OS Open Zoomstack Converted contour and waterline layers from OS OpenZoomstack to polygons then styled as height.

item.title: Lines 2
item.description: I originally started this map under the heading of points, but once I’d worked out the best method it ended up using lines instead. Locating a relocated mile post The photograph on the map layout shows a mile post now on display in a garden in Bishop’s Castle, which Mum and I visited on a Gardens Open Day. My challenge was to work out where the mile post was originally located, based solely on the information it showed.

item.title: Historical
item.description: I still have some ideas I’d like to try out under this heading: Map the Roads from the Isles from the D.D.C. Pochin Mould book. Maybe on an historic map background. Or map shielings or illicit stills in Torridon? Can get Canmore data from Historic Environment Scotland. Bishop’s Castle Railway Partly inspired by old geological maps which have comments around the outside of the geology. For example, the 1893 map of Gairloch which can be seen in the BGS Maps Portal.

item.title: Population
item.description: For this map I followed a Dynamic infographic map tutorial. Estimated population of England by Region, mid-2021 Data From Office for National Statistics. Tools I used QGIS What did I learn? Using population data to show how to set colours in map and charts using variables. Worked out how to find a colour palette which should be “safe” colours. What do I want to change? Could do with sorting out fonts and text sizes.

item.title: Hexagons
item.description: For more information on using hexagons I want to read this article on Hexagons for location intelligence. Species diversity reports from Shropshire Data Data from NBN Atlas - downloaded data for flowering plants in Shropshire, Telford and The Wrekin then extracted particular species. Photo is a field maple in a hedgerow at The Wintles, Bishop’s Castle, April 2022. Tools I used QGIS What did I learn? Creating a virtual layer to run SQL queries.

item.title: Monochrome
item.description: The inspiration for this map came from a tutorial on mapping with hachures by Robin Hawkes. Hachures map of Bishop’s Castle area, South Shropshire Tools I used QGIS What did I learn? Using geometry generators to create hachures. Created visual model in qgis for the process, and discovered how to apply a style file (.qml) as part of the model. That it’s “hachures” not “hatchures”!

item.title: The Earth is not flat
item.description: Joyplots are nicknamed as such after an album cover by the band, Joy Division. The more official name is ridge-line plots. Cwm Mawr Dingle and The Novers joyplot with D.E.M. Slicer Joy plot of an area near Bishop’s Castle in South-west Shropshire. Data 1 m DTM Lidar downloaded from Defra Survey Data Download. Tools I used QGIS with the D.E.M. Slicer plugin. What did I learn? How to use the plugin.

item.title: Data challenge: OpenStreetMap
item.description: Looking at OpenStreetMap data for Shropshire I realised there was a lot of landuse mapped in the South West of the county, around Bishop’s Castle and Clun Forest. So I started thinking what I could do with that. The multipolygon layers also contained administrative boundaries, e.g. with admin_level = 10. Apparently those are civil parishes. So I decided to compare the ratio of woodland/forest to area in a selection of parishes.

item.title: Points
item.description: Firefly cartography April 2022 Points glowing against a dark background. Data Cities data from Natural Earth Data. (Which dataset?) Tools used QGIS What did I learn? The effectiveness of draw effects in QGIS. Firefly cartography! How to create firefly cartography with QGIS

item.title: Urban/Rural
item.description: People living in single person households in Shropshire and Telford and Wrekin Tools I used QGIS What did I learn? A chance to explore a new dataset - NOMIS - rural and urban classification. Doesn’t work as a bivariate choropleth because areas are either rural or urban, not a combination. What do I want to change? Try with a different data variable?

item.title: Boundaries
item.description: My personal bounding box That is, the boundary surrounding places I have visited. Data Natural Earth Data OpenStreetMap data Tools I used QGIS with Globe Builder plugin which became available as of January 2022. What did I learn? Some of this was on first attempt before the Globe Builder plugin became available: How to set up a globe to use as a location map. Custom projections in QGIS. What do I want to change?

item.title: Map with a new tool
item.description: Whitebox Tools: The catchment of the River Kemp, South Shropshire Tools I used Whitebox Tools QGIS What did I learn? I used Whitebox Tools via the python whitebox tools runner interface to generate watershed and hypsometric tinting. This is my new tool. Whitebox Tools has very limited support for coordinate reference systems at the moment. Using shapeburst styled polygons to highlight watershed in a QGIS layout (from van der Kwast hydrology book).

item.title: The Earth is not flat
item.description: Joyplots are nicknamed as such after an album cover by the band, Joy Division. The more official name is ridge-line plots. Beinn Alligin joyplot Elevation drawn as vector lines Data SRTM data downloaded via Earth Explorer Tools I used QGIS with instructions from Drawing elevation as vector lines What did I learn? Using vector lines to show terrain. What do I want to change? Would like to try with more detailed data.

item.title: Map made without using a computer
item.description: There are lots of possibilities for this, and I do want to try and do something new at some point. Embroidery? Crochet? Buttons? Cross stitch map of Shropshire Design by Heritage Crafts. This is a bit of a cheat because I stitched it back in 1991.
